title: Multiple Myeloma Diagnostic Criteria (IMWG)
description: Diagnoses multiple myeloma according to the International Myeloma Working Group (IMWG) criteria, including traditional CRAB criteria and newer SLiM biomarkers.

parameters.name: hypercalcemia
parameters.description: Hypercalcemia: Serum calcium >1 mg/dL above normal or >11 mg/dL

parameters.name: renal_insufficiency
parameters.description: Renal insufficiency: Creatinine clearance <40 mL/min or serum creatinine >2 mg/dL

parameters.name: anemia
parameters.description: Anemia: Hemoglobin >2 g/dL below normal or <10 g/dL

parameters.name: bone_lesions
parameters.description: Bone lesions: ≥1 osteolytic lesion on imaging

parameters.name: light_chain_ratio
parameters.description: Involved:uninvolved serum free light chain ratio ≥100

ranges.description: Criteria not met for multiple myeloma
ranges.interpretation: The patient does not meet the IMWG criteria for multiple myeloma diagnosis. Further evaluation may be needed for other plasma cell disorders.
The patient meets the IMWG criteria for multiple myeloma diagnosis and requires appropriate staging and treatment planning.

references: Rajkumar SV, Dimopoulos MA, Palumbo A, Blade J, Merlini G, Mateos MV, et al. International Myeloma Working Group updated criteria for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. Lancet Oncol. 2014;15(12):e538-48. doi: 10.1016/S1470-2045(14)70442-5.

Kumar S, Paiva B, Anderson KC, Durie B, Landgren O, Moreau P, et al. International Myeloma Working Group consensus criteria for response and minimal residual disease assessment in multiple myeloma. Lancet Oncol. 2016;17(8):e328-e346. doi: 10.1016/S1470-2045(16)30206-6.

Palumbo A, Avet-Loiseau H, Oliva S, Lokhorst HM, Goldschmidt H, Rosinol L, et al. Revised International Staging System for Multiple Myeloma: A Report From International Myeloma Working Group. J Clin Oncol. 2015;33(26):2863-9. doi: 10.1200/JCO.2015.61.2267.
formula: Multiple Myeloma Diagnosis = (Clonal plasma cells ≥10% OR Biopsy-proven plasmacytoma) AND ≥1 myeloma defining event (CRAB criteria: Hypercalcemia, Renal insufficiency, Anemia, Bone lesions; OR SLiM biomarkers: ≥60% plasma cells, Light chain ratio ≥100, >1 MRI focal lesion)
notes: The IMWG criteria require both clonal plasma cell evidence AND myeloma defining events
Traditional CRAB criteria represent end-organ damage from multiple myeloma
SLiM biomarkers (2014 update) allow diagnosis before end-organ damage occurs
SLiM stands for: 60% plasma cells, Light chain ratio ≥100, MRI >1 focal lesion
CRAB stands for: Calcium elevation, Renal dysfunction, Anemia, Bone lesions
Clonal plasma cells must be confirmed by flow cytometry, immunohistochemistry, or immunofluorescence
Plasmacytoma diagnosis requires tissue biopsy confirmation
Hypercalcemia: >1 mg/dL above upper limit of normal or >11 mg/dL
Renal insufficiency: Creatinine clearance <40 mL/min or serum creatinine >2 mg/dL
Anemia: >2 g/dL below lower limit of normal or <10 g/dL
Bone lesions: One or more osteolytic lesions on skeletal radiography, CT, or PET-CT
Light chain ratio: Involved to uninvolved serum free light chain ratio ≥100
MRI focal lesions: More than one focal lesion on MRI studies
60% plasma cells: Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥60%
Concurrent medical conditions may complicate the interpretation of these criteria
Additional testing may include serum protein electrophoresis, immunofixation, and cytogenetics
The criteria distinguish multiple myeloma from MGUS and smoldering multiple myeloma
Early treatment may prevent progression to symptomatic multiple myeloma
Requires comprehensive hematologic evaluation and multidisciplinary care
Regular monitoring is essential for patients meeting diagnostic criteria
